content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include new definitions such as 'private fund' and 'foreign private fund adviser'. These definitions clarify the types of entities and individuals covered under the Act. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include new definitions for entities exempt from registration requirements, such as those with fewer than 15 clients in the US and assets under $25,000,000. These entities cannot hold themselves out as investment advisers to the public or act as advisers to registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 allows for the formation of a development company under section 54, which must not have withdrawn its election. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, a new subparagraph is added for advisers of private funds. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. A new subparagraph is added for advisers of small business investment companies licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, entities with pending license applications, or related applicants. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. A new subparagraph is added for advisers of small business investment companies licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, entities with pending license applications, or related applicants. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. The Commission is authorized to provide reports or records to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and other entities with systemic risk responsibility. Records and reports of private funds advised by registered investment advisers are deemed to be the adviser's records. Required information includes assets under management for each private fund. The subsection requires reporting on assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, practices, and other relevant information for each private fund advised by the investment adviser. Optional additional information may be required by the Commission. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information as deemed necessary for assessing systemic risk. Different reporting requirements may be set based on the types or sizes of private funds advised. Investment advisers must maintain records of private funds for periods prescribed by the Commission. The Commission may prescribe periods for examinations of private fund records maintained by registered investment advisers for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Investment advisers must make records available to the Commission upon request. The adviser registered under this Act must provide copies or extracts of records to the Commission upon request. The Commission will share this information with the Federal Reserve and other entities for assessing systemic risk of private funds. The purpose of assessing systemic risk of a private fund is to provide reports, records, and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors as prescribed by the Commission for the protection of investors and for the assessment of systemic risk. Confidentiality of the information obtained from the Commission must be maintained. The Commission is not required to disclose any report or information filed with them under this subsection, ensuring confidentiality. However, they must still provide information to Congress, other federal agencies, self-regulatory organizations, or comply with court orders. The court order in a US action brought by the United States or the Commission is considered a statute for disclosure purposes under section 552 of title 5, US Code. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision and provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the requirement to maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt certain private fund advisers from registration requirements, with the obligation to maintain records and report to the Commission. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. These exempted advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt private fund advisers with assets under $150,000,000 from registration. The Commission will regulate mid-sized private fund advisers based on their size, governance, and investment strategy to assess systemic risk. Registration and examination procedures will be tailored to the level of risk posed by these funds. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt private fund advisers with assets under $150,000,000 from registration. The Commission will regulate mid-sized private fund advisers based on their size, governance, and investment strategy to assess systemic risk. Registration and examination procedures will be tailored to the level of risk posed by these funds. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to give the Commission authority to make rules and regulations based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk potential. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission the authority to establish rules and regulations based on factors such as size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk potential. The Commission may prescribe different requirements for different classes of persons or matters and ascribe different meanings to terms as necessary. Additionally, a new subsection is added regarding the Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to establish rules and regulations. A new subsection is added for the Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to jointly promulgate rules within 12 months. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements under the Act. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Effective date and transition period are also addressed. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period. The Securities and Exchange Commission will provide rules for advisers to register before the effective date. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. The Commission will adjust dollar amount tests for inflation every 5 years. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
